author: sofi.heessen
title: Catalyst Systems Innovators
description: How do we continuously improve the way we communicate and collaborate? How do we foster an open and sharing culture among active members?

f6_assessments.q0: The challenge certainly matches with the creating a group of people willing to contribute to the ecosystem goal as mentioned in the challenge although alignment with the other two Fund 9 strategic goals is not as well conveyed. How the challenge System Innovator role interrelates and is differentiated from the proposed DReps and Catalyst Circle roles would be a beneficial addition. How System Innovators accountability would be handled, especially under the current monthly project reporting process would also be a beneficial addition.
f6_assessments.q1: There should be no issues with finding 25 individuals within the Catalyst community meeting the qualifications, especially at the proposed salary (6 months = 26 weeks; 26 * 8 hours per week = 208 hours; $12,000 / 208 = $57.69 USD per hour). It is up to the voter to determine if this rate seems reasonable based upon the deliverables and accountability levels described in the challenge.
f6_assessments.q2: The success criteria is fine but the challenge should explain how to measure, "Increased sense of community, more collaboration and idea sharing outside of Ideascale." and "Continued engagement and collaboration among the cohort members". Success criteria indicates tangible outcomes which could better measure progress in quantitative terms.

f6_assessments.q0:
While aiming improvement of communication and collaboration between catalyst members, this challenge does not directly call for proposals. 

The brief describes a worker selection process where proposer must commit to a minimum of 8 working hours and are paid with a fixed and predetermined rewards. Proposer are invited to prove their skills and motivation to get voted on. 

This challenge setting proposal is pioneering, but it is far from what is expected in Fund9 Challenge setting. Even if one strategic goal is to “prepare a group of people willing and able to make contribution to the ecosystem”, the principle of Catalyst in Ideascale is to call for “ideas”.

A challenge setting proposal must define a challenge, a theme, for which here proposers will offer projects or ideas that will be funded. The “group of people” is supposed to be prepared through the proposals that will be developed, not directly hired. The principle of funding people gathered around a common goal is neither a challenge proposal nor a normal proposal.
f6_assessments.q1:
Following above impact comment, I consider this challenges setting is unlikely to receive good quality proposal from the community, even if it could be good at selecting highly skilled people.

I recommend to this challenge team rephrasing and submitting again this idea as a proposal instead of a challenge setting proposal. The proposal could seek for a specific funding, that would be used to select and reward skilled people involved in fostering better communication between catalyst members.
f6_assessments.q2: I understand that success criteria for this challenge is to effectively gather skilled people in a Catalyst System Innovators group. I guess it is precise enough to be evaluated. However, if we consider the question as “can we measure the progress of the Catalyst System Innovators group” then the brief is not complete enough. I recommend adding details about how the progress of this work will be evaluated and communicated to the community (apart from the discord server dedicated to innovators).

f6_assessments.q0:
This challenge is very different in that it seeks to fund regular contributors to the ecosystem. These could be people who coordinate collaboration between different teams, but also mentors, documentors and other supportive roles. A person submits a proposal. Each one who is accepted would be paid a fixed $2000 per month over 6 months. The alignment score is set based on two sets of metrics that define whether a given challenge is critical to achieving Cardano’s mission: the fund9 strategic goals and the guiding questions for challenge setting.

In terms of strategic goals, this challenge meets two: to prepare a group to contribute to the ecosystem and open sourcing. Open-source grassroots organisations have failed in the past due to a lack of basic personnel infrastructure. Hence this also aligns with the open sourcing strategic goal. In terms of voter enthusiasm, this has some potential of achieving this as this would be a very unique opportunity wherein a decentralised global community has hiring decisions to make. It would not be a springboard for greater adoption, however but is very much something that is crucial for the longer vision of Cardano as it is a key pillar of a functioning ecosystem.
f6_assessments.q1: Does the community have the capacity to address this? Without doubt. There is currently a team of more than 10 people working through QA-DAO and the Catalyst Circle Admin team with many many more contributing as volunteers. If given the opportunity, as a CA/vCA and proposer myself, I am certain that many more would apply to work with Catalyst or Cardano full time.
f6_assessments.q2: They offer two dimension of metrics. One that is “Increased sense of community, more collaboration and idea sharing outside of Ideascale.”, which is not easily measurable but could be so through the use of forms and surveying. Collaboration could be quantified if we assume that the funded people keep track on how many connections they are facilitating. I suggest proposers make this a separate KPI and explicitly make this a demand. The second strand of metrics is “Continued engagement and collaboration among the cohort members”. This can also be measured in terms of surveying and close tracking of the number of collaborations that the funded proposers have facilitated (as opposed to generally). It is important that we measure the value-added of this challenge in particular, and not just general trends.

f6_assessments.q0: To begin with, yes, I fully agree with the argument that communication and collaboration will always increase the likelihood of synergy between individuals or groups. But I do not find enough evidence or justification within the challenge settings that demonstrates that this is a major shortcoming within Catalyst today in order to justify the need to allocate a specific Treasury fund for solving this type of problem. In spite of that, I believe the proposal presented by the proposers still merits consideration as part of this governance experiment known as Catalyst. In terms of aligning with strategic goals, it prepares a group of people to contribute to the system. There is, however, no indication of alignment with the other two.
f6_assessments.q1: Indeed, I believe we have enough talent within the Catalyst community and the Cardano community in general to meet this challenge. Actually, I believe that today, in one way or another, there are already individuals who contribute to the community and can easily meet the challenge's requirements. My only concern is that there are at least 2 other challenges competing for selection that are similar to the approach sought here, so my recommendation and as a first model of "collaboration" is that synergies can be found between the various challenge teams with similar focus and present a challenge that includes all perspectives. I bring this up because I consider that there is a possibility of the community's response capacity being diluted across different challenges with similar focuses, which may result in an inefficient allocation of Treasury resources.
f6_assessments.q2: From the perspective of verifiability, I would consider the definition of the success criteria and the suggested set of metrics to be very generic and vague, which renders them difficult to measure. A recommendation would be to include considerations for proposers in terms of reporting structure, expected deliverables, and so forth, in the challenge settings. However, due to the nature of the challenge, I believe that the community has the necessary resources to audit the potential proposers who are selected to receive funds.

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposer here has an idea for a challenge dedicated to people who want to come up with ideas on how to make Project Catalyst a better place.
While this sounds good on its face, I have doubts about the efficacy of this approach, which I will present below. 
First of all, the premise is that we need to set time aside to focus on how to get better at solving problems, not just solve them. While I agree with this, I would argue that we are constantly doing this already and we have been doing it more and more every fund. We have the Catalyst Circle which spends most of its time deliberating on how to improve Project Catalyst and then we have small workgroups (like CA’s and vCA’s) who constantly come up with ideas on how to improve the process (we’ve seen dozens of ideas, listed in documents, every fund). So, in my opinion, there’s no shortage of ideas for improvement. The bottleneck is in implementing them and this (mostly) still resides in IOG’s court. To put this bluntly, personally I’m concerned that proposals in this challenge would only be people coming up with ideas to get the promised money (more on that below), while not actually caring if they are good or if they get implemented at all.
Also, the proposer states that the current system is not really suited to funding facilitators, connectors, mentors etc, but I disagree: we have the Catalyst Swarm and this group is doing exactly that: it’s providing Catalyst funding to members so that they will hold community events, facilitate innovation, maintain the Discord server, create documentation etc.
To finish off my analysis here, I also think that the key metrics to measure are very, very general. For example, “Increased sense of community, more collaboration and idea sharing outside of Ideascale”. I’m sorry, but without concrete numbers, this will be impossible to measure, not to mention that sense of community is something quite vague. I’m not trying to put down this idea, I’m just pointing out that it needs to be more rigorous if it is to gain traction.
To sum up, I do not agree that this particular challenge is critical to achieving Cardano’s mission of mass adoption (mainly because what it intends to do is already happening!). Score: 2.
f6_assessments.q1:
As in the section above, I have serious doubts here as well. The proposer’s idea is to have this challenge be a place where so called System Innovators would be able to place their proposals (for a set amount of 12000 USD, meaning 2000 USD per month for 6 months), with the ultimate goal of having 25 of them funded, so that they would do community service activities for 8 hours per week.
Now my main issue with this approach is that this will be a honey pot for people who want to make some easy money. The way Catalyst works is that funded proposers send a report monthly to IOG and they get their funds. We do not have a way (and it would be absurd) to track if people actually put in the 8 hours of work per week, or if they just write 2 pages of documentation on some subject and then get their 2000 USD for the month, after they send their report that “they did their job”. Furthermore, people would be incentivized to come up with ideas which are not practical, but just sound good, just so they can “deliberate” on them (which might just mean talking with other people on Telegram for example) and then again, receive money as “System Innovators” who tried to think about better ways to do things.
Again, I do not want this to sound harsh, but I have close to 8 years of experience working in IT and I’m painfully aware of the fact that there are people always looking to attach themselves as leeches to profitable endeavors, fooling the management with buzzwords and convincing them they will innovate their culture, while all they do is talk and host the occasional meeting where they offer generic self-help nonsense. Unfortunately, snake oil salesmen are everywhere and they would instantly jump on an opportunity like the one presented here.
As I stated before, the community is already doing everything this proposal wants to incentivize them to do and I actually think having this challenge would only bring more noise and confusion to Project Catalyst. Score: 2.
f6_assessments.q2: In regards to verifiability, I’m afraid this part suffers from being too general as well. First of all, the description for what it means to be an innovator could apply to almost anyone participating in the ecosystem and having a discussion: “Seeks to coordinate and connect”, “works across boundaries”, “Embraces complexity” etc. Second, the description of what proposals should focus on is again extremely vague: “motivation”, “area of focus”, “connections with other proposers” etc. These are simply much too broad concepts to be enforced in any way. I could add anything positive to my proposal and argue that I fulfill the criteria for motivation. To conclude, I cannot find any concrete measure here for how what comes out of this challenge will bring higher value than other projects which aim to actually build tech, or community hubs, or anything that is quantifiable. Score: 2. This being said, I do appreciate what the proposer intended to do and please take what I wrote as constructive criticism.

f6_assessments.q0:
I see a direct alignment of this challenge with the Catalyst Fund9 Challenge Setting Strategic Goals, more precisely item 1(Prepare a group of people willing and able to make contributions to the ecosystem), so this challenge is something important in Cardano's mission.

My caveat is that this challenge setting could better articulate the potential directions of the challenge. The potential/focus directions below are very subjective, which brings uncertainty about what kind of contribution could be made to the challenge.

"-motivation
-previous engagement in Catalyst
-connections with other proposers
-area of ​​focus
-examples of activities"

"-Seeks to coordinate and connect
-works across boundaries
-Looks for emergence
-Embraces complexity
-Thinks holistically
-Innovates"


I understand that the challenge is focused on giving space and funding to contributors, but it is not clear if there is a specific area of ​​interest and the suggestions for focus and the definition of what would be a system inovator bring confusion to the purpose of the challenge, which makes it difficult understand alignment.
f6_assessments.q1:
The Cardano community contains several people who can fit the target roles mentioned for this challenge (facilitators, connectors, documenters, mentors, researchers). Several people already exercise these roles in the community, so the theme of this challenge has the potential to demand in this sense.

The problem I see is that there are already several challenges that allow funding of "facilitators, connectors, documenters, mentors, researchers". It's true that we don't know which challenges will be approved and funded in F9, but in general the roles mentioned in the challenge setting usually have space in different challenges and this can mean that there isn't a great demand for there to be 25 qualified contributors.

It is important to note that there are challenges with relevant overlapping themes that can drain demand from this challenge if funded:

https://cardano.ideascale.com/c/idea/400085
https://cardano.ideascale.com/c/idea/396783
https://cardano.ideascale.com/c/idea/396732

One of the issues that Catalyst is facing is overlapping themes between challenges, which causes confusion and tends not to lead to better utilization of treasure resources. I would recommend that proposers of new challenge settings seek to discuss similar ideas and try to merge if it is something of common interest. Due to the problem of overlapping themes, there is greater uncertainty about the community's ability to meet the challenge with an adequate number of good quality proposals.

It was unclear whether the proposer will create a challenge theam. The only mention related to this was " A common discord server will be set up by the challenge team and used as a way to stay connected.", but it was not clear if the proposer will participate in the challenge team or if there is already a challenge team established.
f6_assessments.q2:
The definition of success and key metrics mentioned are overly subjective. I would recommend defining more tangible and clear items as metrics.

The fact that this challenge setting has a more narrow scope model, limiting participation to solo proposers and limiting the budget makes the audit easier, but as the metrics are not very objective, it will be difficult to assess performance in this challenge.

importance: If we only focus on creating solutions, sometimes together, no one is focussing on how we get better at solving problems together, always
success: A network of Systems Innovators is formed who bring the community together in various constructive ways which lead to tangible outcomes
